thread.title: As his corruption trial begins, John Wiley Price's absence 'very obvious' at Dallas County
thread.title_full: As his corruption trial begins, John Wiley Price's absence 'very obvious' at Dallas County

author: Naomi Martin
title: As his corruption trial begins, John Wiley Price's absence 'very obvious' at Dallas County
text:
Get Unlimited Digital Access Your first month is less than a dollar. $0.99 for first 4 weeks Subscribe Now 
The black leather chair was noticeably empty Tuesday. 
For a long time, it's been the perch from which Dallas County Commissioner John Wiley Price spices up otherwise dry government meetings. Price has been a fixture in that seat wearing his custom-painted bow ties and colorful suits. It's where he sits, cracking jokes and handing out bobbleheads of himself. Minutes later, he's grilling hospital officials and going on tirades about racism in America. 
But on Tuesday morning, his seat sat empty for the first time in years, maybe decades, county officials said. Since he took office in 1985, Price has said, he's never taken vacation. 
Everyone at Commissioners Court knew where Price, 66, was sitting instead. He was seven blocks away in a different kind of court -- U.S. District Court -- for his corruption trial. Hows and whys: Looking back and ahead on John Wiley Price's corruption case before his trial 
"It was very odd today -- his absence was very obvious," said Constable Roy Williams, who has been with the county for 27 years. "It's been a long time since that seat has been vacant on a Tuesday morning." 
While Price's four colleagues ran the meeting without him, dozens of prospective jurors raised their hands to answer a questions about their ability to judge Price fairly. Could they avoid news coverage? Would they hold it against him if he didn't testify? 
Commissioner Elba Garcia said she felt the void to her right. She vowed to seek answers on issues that he was concerned about, such as Parkland Memorial Hospital's financial woes and treatment of patients. 
At one point in the meeting, Garcia did call out asking for a Parkland representative, but he had stepped out. She later said that she was confident Parkland was addressing Price's concerns. Before the trial of his life, John Wiley Price isn't worried 
"We have to be sure that District 3, which is Commissioner Price's district, gets to the table," Garcia said. 
Price could be absent for as long as four months-- the anticipated length of his trial. During that time, Garcia said Price would likely keep up with county business and stay on top of things as best he can. 
"He's a very focused person," she said. Dallas County judge Clay Jenkins reaches for a paper as the seat of Dallas County commissioner John Wiley Price, of district 3, remains vacant during a Dallas County Commissioners Court meeting in the Dallas County Administration Building downtown Dallas Tuesday February 21, 2017. Price is attending the jury selection for his trial where he faces 11 counts of conspiracy to commit bribery, mail fraud and income tax evasion. (Andy Jacobsohn/The Dallas Morning News) Staff Photographer The seat of Dallas County commissioner John Wiley Price, of district 3, remains vacant during a Dallas County Commissioners Court meeting in the Dallas County Administration Building downtown Dallas Tuesday February 21, 2017. Price is attending the jury selection for his trial where he faces 11 counts of conspiracy to commit bribery, mail fraud and income tax evasion. (Andy Jacobsohn/The Dallas Morning News) Staff Photographer Dallas County judge Clay Jenkins during a Dallas County Commissioners Court meeting in the Dallas County Administration Building downtown Dallas Tuesday February 21, 2017. (Andy Jacobsohn/The Dallas Morning News) Staff Photographer The seat of Dallas County commissioner John Wiley Price, of district 3, remains vacant during a Dallas County Commissioners Court meeting in the Dallas County Administration Building downtown Dallas Tuesday February 21, 2017. Price is attending the jury selection for his trial where he faces 11 counts of conspiracy to commit bribery, mail fraud and income tax evasion. (Andy Jacobsohn/The Dallas Morning News) Staff Photographer The seat of Dallas County commissioner John Wiley Price, of district 3, remains vacant during a Dallas County Commissioners Court meeting in the Dallas County Administration Building downtown Dallas Tuesday February 21, 2017. Price is attending the jury selection for his trial where he faces 11 counts of conspiracy to commit bribery, mail fraud and income tax evasion. (Andy Jacobsohn/The Dallas Morning News) Staff Photographer Dallas County commissioners Dr. Theresa Daniel, of district 1, and Mike Cantrell, of district 2, during a Dallas County Commissioners Court meeting in the Dallas County Administration Building downtown Dallas Tuesday February 21, 2017. (Andy Jacobsohn/The Dallas Morning News) Staff Photographer Dallas County commissioner Mike Cantrell, of district 2, before a Dallas County Commissioners Court meeting in the Dallas County Administration Building downtown Dallas Tuesday February 21, 2017. (Andy Jacobsohn/The Dallas Morning News) Staff Photographer The seat of Dallas County commissioner John Wiley Price, of district 3, remains vacant before a Dallas County Commissioners Court meeting in the Dallas County Administration Building downtown Dallas Tuesday February 21, 2017. Price is attending the jury selection for his trial where he faces 11 counts of conspiracy to commit bribery, mail fraud and income tax evasion. (Andy Jacobsohn/The Dallas Morning News) Staff Photographer The seat of Dallas County commissioner John Wiley Price, of district 3, remains vacant as a photograph is made with commissioners and judge Clay Jenkins during a Dallas County Commissioners Court meeting in the Dallas County Administration Building downtown Dallas Tuesday February 21, 2017. Price is attending the jury selection for his trial where he faces 11 counts of conspiracy to commit bribery, mail fraud and income tax evasion. (Andy Jacobsohn/The Dallas Morning News) Staff Photographer Inside the court during a Dallas County Commissioners Court meeting in the Dallas County Administration Building downtown Dallas Tuesday February 21, 2017. (Andy Jacobsohn/The Dallas Morning News) Staff Photographer The seat of Dallas County commissioner John Wiley Price, of district 3, remains vacant before a Dallas County Commissioners Court meeting in the Dallas County Administration Building downtown Dallas Tuesday February 21, 2017. Price is attending the jury selection for his trial where he faces 11 counts of conspiracy to commit bribery, mail fraud and income tax evasion. (Andy Jacobsohn/The Dallas Morning News) Staff Photographer 
County Judge Clay Jenkins said he wasn't concerned about the lack of representation for Price's district, which covers the southern part of the county and has mostly minority residents. Price is the first and only black Dallas County commissioner. Garcia is Hispanic; the other three court members are white. 
"He'll stay focused on his district," Jenkins said. "My district is the entire county so I focus on the entire county. I'll make sure that the people of that district -- I'll focus on them like I always do." 
Price is charged with accepting nearly $1 million in bribes over a decade from businesses seeking contracts or other approvals from the county. If convicted of all charges, he could face up to decades in prison. 
Price has vehemently denied the allegations. He has said after his acquittal, he'll be right back to work. What's next? 
Key upcoming dates in the John Wiley Price public corruption trial: 
Today: Jury selection starts, and could run through Friday. 
Feb. 24 or 27: Testimony expected to begin, soon after a jury is seated. 
June 30: Prosecution and defense attorneys have agreed to wrap up the trial before this date. View Comments
